round_data.prompt:
You and another agent have to negotiate a division of items between the two of you.
    You are Player 1 and the other agent is Player 2.
    There are 5 types of items, called item 1 through item 5.
    There are 2 units of item 1, 2 units of item 2, 6 units of item 3, 2 units of item 4, 3 units of item 5 to divide.
    Both you and Player 2 have a private value per unit of each item type.
    These values are drawn from a uniform random distribution, ranging from 1 to 101.
    Your private values are 73 for item 1, 35 for item 2, 57 for item 3, 67 for item 4, 20 for item 5.
    You have a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to your total value of all items, which is 752. Player 2 has a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to to their total value of all items.
    Your outside offer value is 521. 

    The negotiation proceeds in 3 rounds.
    There is a discount rate gamma = 0.98, such that if the process concludes after r rounds the overall value of the negotiation to each player is their value for the outcome multiplied by gamma to the power (r-1).
    At each round, Player 1 takes an action, followed by Player 2.
    The possible actions are to ACCEPT the other player's current offer (if any), make a COUNTEROFFER, or WALK away.  If the game gets to the last round, and player 2 chooses to make a counteroffer, this is treated as a WALK.
    If a player chooses ACCEPT, the negotiation ends in a deal to divide the items according to the accepted offer.
    The value of an outcome is determined by each player's private values per unit of each item and the quantities they receive in the deal. This value is adjusted by the discount factor, which is used to compute the present value of the negotiation outcome.
    If a player chooses WALK, the negotiation ends without a deal, and each player receives the value of their private outside offer.

    Please show your reasoning step by step, then provide your action in one of these formats in your response (if you do not do this your response will be invalid):
    {"action": "ACCEPT"} - to accept the current offer
    {"action": "WALK"} - to walk away from negotiations  
    {"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [n1, n2, ...]} - where n1, n2, ... are numbers representing the number of units of each item being offered to the other player as part of the counteroffer.

    Any response not in these exact formats will be invalid and treated as a WALK. If you provide a counteroffer, it must be a valid offer, otherwise it will be treated as a WALK.

    It is now round 1.
    
 Negotiation history:

Current offer on the table (the amount of each item being offered to you): None

        What is your action? As the first player, your available actions are:
        - WALK to walk away
        - A list of numbers [n1, n2, ...] representing your initial offer (what you give to Player 2)
round_data.response:
Step 1. We first note that if the agreement were to give us everything, our “raw” value would be 752. However, we have an outside option (521) that we must beat; so in any deal our own payoff must be at least 521. That means we may “buy” extra acceptability with Player 2 using up to (752 – 521) = 231 “points” of our own value. (Remember that payoffs are computed by multiplying the number of units we get by our private per‐unit value, and there is no discounting in round 1.)

Step 2. Our private per‑unit values are as follows:
 • Item 1: 73
 • Item 2: 35
 • Item 3: 57
 • Item 4: 67
 • Item 5: 20

In contrast, Player 2’s private values are drawn uniformly from 1 to 101 so his “typical” per‑unit average is about 51. (We never know his exact values, but this is our best “expected” estimate.) Thus the “exchange ratio” (expected gain for Player 2 divided by our loss) if we give over one unit is approximately:
 • Item 1: 51/73 ≈ 0.70 
 • Item 2: 51/35 ≈ 1.46
 • Item 3: 51/57 ≈ 0.89 
 • Item 4: 51/67 ≈ 0.76 
 • Item 5: 51/20 = 2.55

Step 3. It is wise (for our own payoff) to concede those items for which the opponent “gains” much more (in expectation) relative to the cost in our own terms. That is, we want to hand over items with high “value‐ratio” for Player 2 and low cost for us. From above, item 5 is best and item 2 is also good. (By contrast, items 1 and 4 hurt us more than they help with acceptance.)

Step 4. A reasonably “generous‐yet‐self‐favouring” plan is as follows. We propose that Player 2 receive:
 • All of item 2 (all 2 units) 
 • All of item 5 (all 3 units)
Since these items cost us relatively little (2×35 + 3×20 = 70 + 60 = 130 “points”) and give him an expected gain of roughly (2×51 + 3×51 = 102 + 153 = 255), this concession may help nudge him toward accepting our proposal.

Step 5. In order to “top‐up” Player 2’s expected utility further, we can also concede one unit of an item that does not cost us too much extra. Among the remaining items, item 3 (with cost 57 to us and an expected 51 benefit for him) is preferable to item 1 or 4 (which are even costlier for us relative to his benefit). Conceding 1 unit of item 3 raises his expected takings by about 51 to a total (expected) of 306.

Step 6. Under this proposed division the total available items [2, 2, 6, 2, 3] are split as follows:
 • Offer to Player 2: [item1: 0, item2: 2, item3: 1, item4: 0, item5: 3]
 • Our remainder: [item1: 2, item2: 0, item3: (6 – 1) = 5, item4: 2, item5: 0]

Our own value then is:
 Item 1: 2 × 73 = 146
 Item 3: 5 × 57 = 285
 Item 4: 2 × 67 = 134
 Total = 146 + 285 + 134 = 565, which beats our outside offer of 521.

Step 7. Although we do not know Player 2’s exact outside offer or private values, an expected total of roughly 306 (from the items we’re giving him) is a plausible “bargaining share” for him in round 1. (Had we tried to secure even more of his “expected pie” by conceding extra high‐expected‐value items, our own payoff would drop dangerously close to or below our alternative of 521.)

Step 8. Therefore, a reasonable initial offer from our side is to propose handing Player 2 the following bundle:
 [0, 2, 1, 0, 3]

Thus, in the required format our action is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 2, 1, 0, 3]}

    The following step-by-step questions are designed to guide you through a comprehensive analysis. By systematically addressing these questions, you can evaluate the current state of the negotiation, assess potential offers, and make informed decisions. You must use the information that you acquired through the step-by-step questioning above to decide what action you will make.
    Let's walk through this step by step:

    1) First, analyze the current situation:
       - What is my outside offer value?
       - What are the values of the items involved?
       - What is the total pool of items?
       - How does the discount factor influence the value of accepting the current offer versus waiting for future offers?

    2) Assess the value of offers:
       - For the current offer (if any): What is my total value if I accept it?
       - For potential counteroffers: What would be my total value for different proposed divisions?
       - How do these values compare to my outside offer value?

    3) Make a decision based on the analysis:
       - Should I accept the current offer?
       - Should I walk away and take my outside offer?
       - Or should I propose a specific counteroffer?

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    To prevent these mistakes, adopt a strategy similar to the following example: Before making any counteroffer, 
    calculate its total value to you and compare it to your outside offer value. For instance, suppose you keep only [0, 0, 5, 2, 1] items and offer the rest to the other party. Your value would be:
    35 x 0 + 23 x 0 + 77 x 5 + 48 x 2 + 10 x 1
    which is 491 (sum of all item values)
    
    which is less than your outside offer of 492. If your proposed offer results in a value lower than your outside offer, continue iterating until you develop a more advantageous offer that is better than your outside offer. 
    This reasoning can be applied to each of the five highlighted mistakes to ensure that your offers align with your objectives and avoid undesirable negotiation behaviors.

    Keep in mind the offers the opposing agent makes reflects its own values. If their offer includes most or all units of a particular item, it might indicate that the agent does not highly value that item, whereas offering none could suggest the opposite. 
    You can use this kind of evidence to help inform your decision-making.

    Please show your reasoning step by step, then provide your action in one of these formats in your response (if you do not do this your response will be invalid):
    {"action": "ACCEPT"} - to accept the current offer
    {"action": "WALK"} - to walk away from negotiations  
    {"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [n1, n2, ...]} - where n1, n2, ... are numbers representing the number of units of each item being offered to the other player as part of the counteroffer.

    Any response not in these exact formats will be invalid and treated as a WALK. If you provide a counteroffer, it must be a valid offer, otherwise it will be treated as a WALK.

    It is now round 1.
    
 Negotiation history:
Round 1: Player 1 offered [0, 2, 1, 0, 3]

Current offer on the table (the amount of each item being offered to you): [0, 2, 1, 0, 3]

    What is your action? You can:
    - ACCEPT to accept the current offer
    - WALK to walk away
    - A list of numbers [n1, n2, ...] representing your counteroffer (what you give to Player 1)
round_data.response:
I need to analyze whether to accept the current offer, walk away, or make a counteroffer.

Step 1: Analyze the current situation
- My outside offer value is 492
- My item values are: 35 for item 1, 23 for item 2, 77 for item 3, 48 for item 4, 10 for item 5
- Total pool: 2 units of item 1, 2 units of item 2, 6 units of item 3, 2 units of item 4, 3 units of item 5
- Discount factor = 0.98, which means each round reduces the value of outcomes

Step 2: Assess the value of the current offer
Player 1 offered me [0, 2, 1, 0, 3]
This means they keep [2, 0, 5, 2, 0]

Let me calculate what I would receive:
- 0 units of item 1 = 0 × 35 = 0
- 2 units of item 2 = 2 × 23 = 46
- 1 unit of item 3 = 1 × 77 = 77
- 0 units of item 4 = 0 × 48 = 0
- 3 units of item 5 = 3 × 10 = 30
Total value = 153

This is significantly less than my outside offer of 492, so accepting would be a mistake.

Step 3: Consider a counteroffer
I should prioritize items with highest value to me:
- Item 3 has the highest value (77 per unit)
- Item 4 is second (48 per unit)
- Item 1 is third (35 per unit)
- Item 2 is fourth (23 per unit)
- Item 5 is lowest (10 per unit)

Let me try to keep most of the high-value items while offering Player 1 enough to make the deal attractive:

If I offer Player 1 [1, 2, 1, 0, 3]:
I keep [1, 0, 5, 2, 0]
My value = 1×35 + 0×23 + 5×77 + 2×48 + 0×10 = 35 + 0 + 385 + 96 + 0 = 516

This exceeds my outside offer of 492, so it's a viable counteroffer.

Let me check if I can do better by giving up more of the lower-valued items:

If I offer Player 1 [2, 2, 1, 0, 3]:
I keep [0, 0, 5, 2, 0]
My value = 0×35 + 0×23 + 5×77 + 2×48 + 0×10 = 0 + 0 + 385 + 96 + 0 = 481

This is less than my outside offer of 492, so it's not a good counteroffer.

I'll make a counteroffer of [1, 2, 1, 0, 3], which means I'll keep [1, 0, 5, 2, 0], giving me a value of 516, which is better than my outside offer of 492.

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 2, 1, 0, 3]}

round_data.response:
After careful consideration, I note the following:

• In the current offer, I would receive [1,2,1,0,3]. Calculating my undiscounted utility:
  item 1: 1×73 = 73  
  item 2: 2×35 = 70  
  item 3: 1×57 = 57  
  item 4: 0×67 = 0  
  item 5: 3×20 = 60  
  Total = 73 + 70 + 57 + 0 + 60 = 260  
When discounted in round 2 (multiplied by 0.98), that becomes about 254.8.

• My private outside offer (which I would get if I WALK) is 521 – far better than the 254.8 I’d get now.

• Any counteroffer I try to craft must, on one hand, guarantee that I end up with an “undiscounted” bundle that (after applying the round 2 discount of 0.98) beats 521 – meaning I’d need more than roughly 532 in undiscounted utility. Since the whole pie is valued 752 by me, that would leave my opponent with 752 – 532 = 220 in my terms. (I do not know their private numbers, but it seems unlikely that they would accept receiving what, by my measure, is so little when their alternative (and their own outside offer) is unknown – but likely not as low as 220.)

• Thus any counteroffer that is “too aggressive” in my favor is unlikely to be acceptable. And if I concede enough to tempt Player 2 to agree, my discount‐adjusted outcome would drop near or even below my outside offer of 521.

Because of that, even though I could try to counteroffer, the strategic situation is such that my reservation value is so high relative to the current division (and any deal I might salvage in round 2) that it would be wiser to WALK and secure my outside option of 521 rather than risk a deal whose present value is far lower.

Therefore, my action is:

{"action": "WALK"}

Step 1: Let’s review the situation. There are 5 item types with a total of 
  • item 1: 6 units, 
  • item 2: 7 units, 
  • item 3: 5 units, 
  • item 4: 5 units, 
  • item 5: 2 units.
My private per‐unit values are:
  • item 1: 29,
  • item 2: 28,
  • item 3: 16,
  • item 4: 44,
  • item 5: 71.
Thus if I got everything, my total value would be 812; however, my private outside offer is 216. (Recall that if negotiations “fail” we each get our outside offer.)

Step 2: As Player 1 in round 1 I must make an initial “offer” – that is, propose an allocation that assigns for each item type a number of units to give to Player 2. In the outcome I would keep the remaining units.

Step 3: My aim is to secure a deal that gives me high value (keeping the items I value most) while offering Player 2 enough expected value so that they prefer the deal over their uncertain outside offer. Although I do not know Player 2’s private values, by assumption each of their per‐unit values is drawn uniformly from 1 to 101 so that on average they are about 51 per unit. In expectation their “whole package” value if they got everything would be about 25×51 ≈1275 and their outside offer (drawn from 1 up to that maximum) would average around 637.5. Thus an offer should roughly promise them at least 650 in expected terms.

Step 4: Because I really value item 5 (71 per unit) and item 4 (44 per unit) compared to my lower‐valued items (item 3 is only 16, and items 1 and 2 are in the high 20s), I prefer to keep items 4 and 5 for myself. To “concede,” I can offer Player 2 the items I care less about. Giving away all 7 units of item 2 (value 28) and all 5 units of item 3 (value 16) is attractive from my standpoint while giving them many units. That would be 7+5 = 12 units in total. In expectation that “bundle” would be worth roughly 12×51 ≈612 to Player 2. That may be a bit low compared to their outside offer. 

Step 5: To “top‐up” the package for Player 2, I can give one unit of item 1 (value 29 to me) in addition. Then the total units given to Player 2 become 1+7+5 = 13 units, with an expected worth of about 13×51 ≈663. This gives Player 2 an expected deal–value higher than the average outside offer while enabling me to keep the high‐value items. 

Step 6: Under this offer my allocation becomes:
  • Offer to Player 2:
   – item 1: 1 unit,
   – item 2: 7 units,
   – item 3: 5 units,
   – item 4: 0 units,
   – item 5: 0 units.
  • I then keep:
   – item 1: 5 (6–1) units,
   – item 2: 0 (7–7) units,
   – item 3: 0 (5–5) units,
   – item 4: 5 units,
   – item 5: 2 units.
My own payoff would be:
  item 1: 5×29 = 145,
  item 4: 5×44 = 220,
  item 5: 2×71 = 142,
  Total = 145 + 220 + 142 = 507.
This outcome (discounted by γ^(0) = 1 since we are in round 1) is better for me than risking walking away (which gives 216). And the offer gives Player 2 an expected value of about 663 (13 units×51), which should be attractive to them.

Step 7: Based on this reasoning, I will make the following initial offer.

I'll explain my reasoning briefly.

My private values are:
 • Item 1: 40  • Item 2: 22  • Item 3: 31  • Item 4: 96  • Item 5: 40
and the totals available are: [9, 4, 4, 8, 2]. If I got every unit I’d have 1420 value.
My outside offer is 942 (and if I were to get a deal in round 2 the payoff is multiplied by γ = 0.98 so I need an “undiscounted” deal worth roughly 942/0.98 ≈ 961 to be at least as good as my outside option).

The current offer on the table is to me [0, 2, 4, 0, 0] (which would give me only 2·22 + 4·31 = 44 + 124 = 168, and discounted that is even lower). So clearly I should reject it.

I now want to propose a counteroffer that leaves me nearly the entire “pie” while still giving Player 2 something attractive enough so that (from their unknown private values) they might prefer this deal to risking a later round (with even more discounting) or their outside offer. 

I want to “keep” most of the high‐value items for me – especially item 4 (worth 96 to me) and item 5 (worth 40) – and concede mainly on items I value less (items 1–3). In particular, to guarantee at least 961 “raw” value for myself I must give away at most 1420 – 961 ≈ 459 (in my value‐terms). To use my “concession budget” efficiently I allocate the concessions to items that cost me little per unit. In my case the lowest per‐unit value is for item 2 (22 per unit) and then item 3 (31 per unit) and finally item 1 (40 per unit).

A candidate that meets these considerations is to offer Player 2:
 • 6 units of item 1, • 4 units of item 2, • 4 units of item 3, • 0 units of item 4, • 0 units of item 5.
Then my share becomes:
 • Item 1: 9 – 6 = 3 units,
 • Item 2: 4 – 4 = 0 units,
 • Item 3: 4 – 4 = 0,
 • Item 4: 8 – 0 = 8,
 • Item 5: 2 – 0 = 2.
My value will be 3×40 + 8×96 + 2×40 = 120 + 768 + 80 = 968. Discounting in round 2 gives 968×0.98 ≈ 948.64, which is slightly above my outside offer of 942.

This counteroffer keeps most of the extremely valuable item 4 (and all of item 5) for me while conceding “cheaper‐to‐me” items. (I note that Player 2’s earlier round action – offering me [0, 2, 4, 0, 0] – implies that they may be expecting to keep much of item 4 and item 5, so they likely have their own strategic reasons for insisting on those. I try to balance my need not to do worse than my outside option with leaving them enough “incentive” so that they might agree rather than walk away.)

Thus, my action is to make the counteroffer:

round_data.response:
After careful analysis, here’s my reasoning:

• In the current round (round 2) the offer on the table gives me [2,2,4,0,0] – meaning that if I ACCEPT I would receive 2 units of item 1, 2 of item 2, 4 of item 3 and nothing of items 4 and 5. Using my private per‐unit values (item 1: 92, item 2: 41, item 3: 86, item 4: 17, item 5: 8), the raw (undiscounted) value of that package is:  
  2×92 + 2×41 + 4×86 = 184 + 82 + 344 = 610.

• Because we are in round 2, any deal is discounted by γ^(r–1)=0.98 so the present value would be 0.98×610 ≈ 598. This is substantially lower than the value of my outside offer, which is 973 (and – importantly – comes without discounting).

• I considered whether I could propose a counteroffer that would give me at least a “raw‐value threshold” that makes the discount factor’s effect (0.98) keep my present value above 973. In round 2 I would need a raw package of roughly 973/0.98 ≈ 994 points. With my item values the only way to exceed this threshold is to secure the bulk of the high‐value items (items 1 and 3) and some of item 2. For example, if I were to keep all of item 1 (6 units) and item 3 (4 units) I get 6×92 + 4×86 = 552 + 344 = 896. Then I’d need to keep at least 3 units of item 2 (3×41 = 123) so that my total raw value is 896+123 = 1019 (which discounted gives about 998). However, such a division would force me to give almost everything in the “lower‐value” items (items 4 and 5) to Player 2 – and worse, I would almost entirely “cut off” items 1 and 3. In comparison, Player 2’s own last offer gave them a package (by getting what I did not claim) that would be very attractive (for instance, their round‑1 offer [2,2,4,0,0] implies they expect to end up with [4,3,0,5,5], a much higher raw total than what they’d get if I demanded nearly all of items 1, 2 and 3).

• Thus, any counteroffer that meets my threshold (needed to beat my outside option) leaves Player 2 with a share markedly lower than what they already appear to prefer. In contrast, accepting the current offer gives me far less than my outside offer.

• Given this, any deal reached through further negotiation in round 2 or round 3 would necessarily yield me a discounted amount lower than my guaranteed outside offer of 973. (And since my outside offer does not get discounted and I know it is available, I can secure that value by ending the negotiations.)

For these reasons the best action for me is to WALK away rather than making a counteroffer that would try to force an agreement on terms that are too unfavorable for Player 2 – which would likely lead to no deal and then eventually my outside offer anyway.

{"action": "WALK"}

round_data.response:
I’ll explain my reasoning.

My “pie” totals 1557 in my own valuation. Since my outside option is 1446, any negotiated deal must give me at least 1446 in value. That means I have only a surplus of 1557 – 1446 = 111 “points” to share with Player 2. (Any deal giving me less than 1446 is worse than simply taking my outside offer.) In an offer we "pay" Player 2 (by “conceding” items) an “amount” measured in my own value. I want to use items for which my own per‐unit value is low (so that “paying” that unit costs me little) while (if possible) giving Player 2 an allocation that—when he applies his own (unknown but on average roughly 51 per unit) values—is at least as attractive as his own outside offer.

Looking at my values:
 • Item 1: 89 per unit  – too expensive to give away.
 • Item 2: 79 per unit  – also relatively dear.
 • Item 3: only 5 per unit  – very “cheap” for me; it makes sense to concede these.
 • Item 4 and Item 5: 71 per unit.

It is natural then to “pay” Player 2 using as many units of item 3 as possible. I have 6 units, and giving all of them “costs” me only 6×5 = 30 of my surplus. That leaves 111 – 30 = 81 “points” to allocate. Unfortunately, every remaining unit of any good costs at least 71 (for either item 4 or item 5, which are lower than my cost on item 2 or item 1). So I can “afford” to give up one additional unit (cost = 71) and still remain within 111 (30 + 71 = 101). (The remaining 10 “points” cannot buy you a whole additional unit since items are indivisible.) 

Thus I can propose to give Player 2 all 6 units of item 3 plus one unit of, say, item 4 (you might equivalently choose item 5). Under this division my “kept” bundle is:
 – Item 1: all 9 units
 – Item 2: all 2 units
 – Item 3: 0 units (since I gave all 6 away)
 – Item 4: 3 – 1 = 2 units
 – Item 5: all 5 units

My value then is:
 Item 1: 9×89 = 801
 Item 2: 2×79 = 158
 Item 4: 2×71 = 142
 Item 5: 5×71 = 355
 Total = 801 + 158 + 142 + 355 = 1456

This is 10 “points” above my outside offer. (It uses “concessions” worth 30 + 71 = 101 in my scale, which is within my available surplus of 111.) 

I realize that (using average estimates for Player 2 where his per‐unit values average around 51) the bundle I’m offering him would “look like” 6×(≈51) + 1×(≈51) ≈ 306 + 51 = 357 in expected value—less than what his outside option might be on average. In a full equilibrium analysis Player 2’s private numbers would matter. But given my very tight surplus (only 111 “points” to share) it is not possible for me to “buy” him a much larger share without reducing my own outcome to below my safe outside option. (That is why my bargaining surplus is extremely limited.) 

Thus, as my initial offer (when I must propose a division), I choose the “most demanding” offer that still gives me slightly more than 1446 while “paying” Player 2 with the best “cheap” items I have. 

My action is therefore to propose a counteroffer with the offer list:
 [0, 0, 6, 1, 0]

In the required response format this is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 0, 6, 1, 0]}

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.

round_data.response:
After careful analysis of the situation, I note the following. My private values for the 5 items add up to 1195. My private outside offer guarantees me 1019 if negotiations break down. In any division of the items the result (my share’s value) is computed using my unit‐values. That means I must secure an outcome that provides me at least 1019 value. Since 1195 is all the items, the “surplus” I could possibly achieve above my disagreement payoff is only 1195 – 1019 = 176. In a division the bundle allocated to Player 2 is worth, in my estimation, the sum of my per‐unit valuations given up. In order to try to “incentivize” Player 2 to accept in round 1 it would be necessary to offer them a bundle that (using an estimate for their values, e.g. about 51 per unit on average) is competitive with what they could get from their own outside offer. Roughly, if Player 2’s total value for all items on average is about 1071, their outside offer will tend to be on the order of half that (say around 535 on average). In order to “buy” Player 2’s agreement, I’d have to concede many item‐units (in expectation about 11 units, since 11×51 ≈561). However, even if I allocated the 11 “cheapest” units (from my perspective) to Player 2 it would cost me far more than the 176 available surplus – in fact, an (almost) optimal choice from my side would be something like giving all of item 5 (2 units, costing me 2×10 = 20) and then as many of item 4 as possible (it costs me 53 per unit) but even then the best I can do while still achieving at least 1019 for me would be to concede only 2 extra units from item 4 (2×53 =106) so that my concession in value is only 20+106 =126. This would supply Player 2 an expected “windfall” of only 4 units ×51 =204 in expected value. In most cases that is far below what Player 2’s outside offer is likely to be. In short, if I try to find a counteroffer that both leaves me with more than my 1019 outside offer and gives Player 2 enough to beat (or even come close to) what they might get on their own, I run into a dilemma: the numbers just don’t work out. Any counteroffer that keeps my value at or above 1019 ends up “leaving” Player 2 a bundle whose expected value is very low (e.g. on the order of 200–250 in expectation) and thus would likely be rejected by a rational Player 2 holding a decent outside offer.

Given that rejecting my counteroffer leads to no discounting in round 1 but can only be improved upon in later rounds (at a cost of discounting the outcome), it appears that in round 1 I am better off “walking away” and securing my outside option of 1019 rather than risking a counteroffer that is too stingy to entice Player 2 to settle.

Thus, based on the trade‐off between what I can “sell” and what I must “buy” for Player 2 (while preserving my own minimum acceptable payoff), my best action in round 1 is to WALK away.

My answer in the required format is:

{"action": "WALK"}

We start by noting that if I got all items my total utility would be

That means on average his outside offer might be around 255. Still, since I do not know his draw I must “probe” the negotiation by offering him something.)

In order to keep my own acceptance level (I need at least 433 in my own value) I can only “sacrifice” up to 587 – 433 = 154 points of value (in my own scoring). Conceding one unit of item 5 costs me 50 points; thus the maximum I can give up purely on item 5 is 3 units (since 3·50 = 150, and 4 units would cost 200, dropping my own value too low).   item 5: remaining 1 unit → 1·50 = 50

(If Player 2’s own outside offer proves high he may well counter; but as first mover I am using my bargaining advantage to see if I can get an acceptable deal with minimal sacrifice.)

Thus, my initial proposal is to give Player 2 3 units of item 5 and nothing else. In the required JSON format my action is:

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

I will explain my thinking before presenting my offer.

(1) My “pie” is worth 573 (in my own valuation) and my disagreement payoff (my outside offer) is 398. Thus any deal I get must leave me with at least 398 in my value‐terms. In other words, the pieces I “keep” must add up to at least 398. (Remember that when I make an offer I propose what items I will give to Player 2; whatever is not given I keep.)

(2) My per‐unit values are different for each item. I value item 1 at 27, item 2 at 34, item 3 at 35, item 4 at only 10, and item 5 at 24. (The totals from each type are: 3 of item 1, 2 of item 2, 6 of item 3, 7 of item 4, and 6 of item 5.)

(3) Since I must “beat” my disagreement value I need to secure at least 398 for myself. At the same time, if I offer too little to Player 2 they will reject my offer and “walk‐away” to get their own outside offer. (Player 2’s own outside offer is privately drawn from 1 up to their total value; even though its expectation is higher than mine, I don’t know their exact values. So if I push too hard my counteroffer may be rejected.)

(4) It is natural to “concede” those items that are (from my perspective) “cheap” – here that is item 4 (worth only 10 to me) and then (if needed) some of item 5 (worth 24 to me). In contrast, I want to keep the items I value highly (item 3 at 35, item 2 at 34, and item 1 at 27).

(5) How much concession can I afford? I have a total of 573 by my numbers and need at least 398 for myself. Thus I can give up items worth at most 175 to Player 2. One “easy” concession is to give all 7 units of item 4. That amounts to 7×10 = 70 (by my value). Then I can concede an extra 175 – 70 = 105 in value. Since each unit of item 5 is worth 24 to me, I can concede at most 4 full units (4×24 = 96) without going below my threshold. (Giving 5 would be 120 and would lower my share too much.)

(6) With this choice I would give Player 2 a total of 7 (of item 4) + 4 (of item 5) = 11 units. My “keep” would then be:
  • item 1: all 3 units,
  • item 2: all 2 units,
  • item 3: all 6 units,
  • item 4: 0 units,
  • item 5: 6 – 4 = 2 units.
My own value then is 3×27 + 2×34 + 6×35 + 0×10 + 2×24 = 81 + 68 + 210 + 0 + 48 = 407, which is safely above my 398 outside offer.
(7) Of course, Player 2’s private values are unknown; on average a player’s per‐unit value (drawn uniformly on 1 to 101) is about 51. If Player 2 “sees” my offer by expecting roughly 51 per unit for the 11 items I offer them, that would be about 561 – which might be a bit lower than what their own outside offer might be if they happened to have a “lucky” draw. However, as the first mover I face some uncertainty and it is typical to start “aggressively.” I know that if we continue negotiating the discount (γ = 0.98 per extra round) makes later outcomes a bit lower; so I place my hope that Player 2’s realization of their own private values is such that this offer is just acceptable.

Based on the above, my action in round 1 is to propose the following division (remember, in the proposal the numbers indicate the number of units I would give to Player 2):

I'm going to try to sketch my reasoning briefly. My “world‐model” is as follows. I have five types of items available in quantities [1, 5, 0, 4, 4] and I value them at [83, 41, 56, 11, 30] respectively. (Item 3 isn’t available.) In total my “all‐items” value is 452 so my outside option (if I “WALK”) is 319. Thus, any deal giving me less than 319 in my own personal “score” isn’t acceptable.

Player 2’s private per‐unit values are drawn uniformly on [1,101] so (roughly) each unit is “worth” about 51 in expectation to them. Their outside offer is drawn uniformly between 1 and their full‐bundle value (which – in expectation – sums to roughly 714). Thus the expected reservation (or disagreement) value for Player 2 is about 357. (These numbers are rough; neither of us knows the other’s draw.) In any acceptable deal Player 2 should get at least roughly the “equivalent” of 357 in expected value. In units this means they’d “like” to be awarded roughly 357/51 ≈ 7 units (of “average‐worth” goods).

At the same time I want to “protect” my own interest: I must get at least 319 points in value. I can “afford” to sacrifice up to 452 – 319 = 133 points from my full value if that sacrifice gets me a deal the opponent will accept. Because my values vary a lot across items (I value item 1 very highly, and item 4 very little), I can “hand over” the lower–value items while keeping the higher–value ones. In my view items 4 and 5 are “cheaper” for me (worth 11 and 30 each) than items 1 (83) or 2 (41). So the idea is to offer Player 2 nearly all of item 4 (which is only 4 units available) and a few units of item 5 so that the total number of “units” they see (and roughly the expected dollar‐worth to them) is about 6–7 units. (If I give them 7 full “expected‐worth” units – that is, if I hand over 4 of item 4 plus 3 of item 5 – that sacrifice would “cost” me 44 + 90 = 134, leaving me with only 318 – one point below my outside offer. That, I believe, is a tight bargain for Player 2 but I’d be hurting myself by a point.) 

Because I do not know Player 2’s actual “draw” (their outside offer and true per–unit values), I choose (in this first round) an offer that is ambitious for me but might be acceptable if they are on the lower side. In the offer below I give Player 2 all 4 of item 4 (valued very low by me) plus only 2 of item 5. That means Player 2 would end up “getting” 6 units (4 + 2) versus about 7 units that the “average” would perhaps expect. My resulting allocation then would be:
 • Item 1: I keep all 1 unit (83 points)
 • Item 2: I keep all 5 units (5×41 = 205 points)
 • Item 4: I give them all 4 units (4×11 = 44 sacrificed points)
 • Item 5: I give them 2 units (2×30 = 60 sacrificed points) and keep 2 units (2×30 = 60 points)
So my total “own‐value” is 83 + 205 + 60 = 348 – comfortably above 319. (Player 2 gets items that are “cheap” for me but on average they might see them as roughly 51 each; 6 units would be about 306 in expectation. That is a bit lower than the ~357 that might be expected, so if Player 2 “happens” to have a high outside offer they might counter. But my hope is that in many cases they’ve drawn a softer number, and I remain in a decent position.)

Because this is a first‐round move and I want to be ambitious while leaving a little “room” for later rounds if needed, I will propose this division.

Thus my action is as follows:

For example, if I were to give all 4 units of item 4 (cost 4×11 = 44) and 2 units of item 5 (cost 2×30 = 60) to Player 2, then my “cost” is 104 and I would keep a share worth 452 – 104 = 348 which, when discounted (0.98×348 ≈ 341), exceeds my outside offer.

However, by doing so I would be offering Player 2 the bundle [0,0,0,4,2]. Notice that if I accepted the current offer instead, I would be forced to accept getting only [0,0,0,0,2] (i.e. I’d “lose” in terms of good items) while Player 2 would automatically obtain the remainder – namely [1,5,0,4,2]. (That current division favors Player 2 handily because they “steal” almost all of items 1 and 2 which I value highly but which they might value even more.) 

In order for my counteroffer to be acceptable to Player 2, it must be “better” (for them) than what they already guarantee themselves by their own offer. Since Player 2’s current offer effectively gives them [1,5,0,4,2] (the items I don’t get when I accept), a counteroffer where I offer only [0,0,0,4,2] would be unattractive to them – they’d be giving up a bundle with extra item 1 and item 2.

In order to make a counteroffer that tempts Player 2 to accept, I’d have to concede some additional high‐value items (from my perspective), for example by giving one unit of item 2 or item 1. But conceding even one unit of item 2 (worth 41 to me) would push the “cost” into ranges where my own share (the cake I keep) would drop below the 325.5 threshold. In other words, any counteroffer that would “beat” Player 2’s current terms from their perspective would force me into a deal with an outcome lower than my outside option of 319 (after discounting).

Thus, while I would prefer to “reach an agreement” (since negotiating and discounting further always hurts both sides), any realistic counteroffer that I can credibly propose – one that leaves me with an acceptable share and yet exceeds the bundle Player 2 already gets by their own offer – appears infeasible. 

Given that accepting the current offer nets me an immediate (discounted) 58.8, and any counteroffer that would win Player 2’s acceptance would leave me with less than my outside value of 319, my best course is to WALK away and secure the outside option.

Therefore, my action is:

{"action": "WALK"}

Our private outside option is 627, so any deal we settle on must yield us more than 627 (when not discounted as we are in round 1). 

Step 2: Consider which items are “precious” to us versus which we can concede.
 – Item 3 is our highest‐value (87 per unit) so we want to keep all 5 units.
 – Items 4 and 5 are also relatively valuable (59 and 55) but only moderately above a likely average opponent value (for Player 2 a typical per‐unit value might be around the midpoint of the 1–101 range, roughly 51). It is therefore acceptable to concede a few units of these.
 – Items 1 and 2 – with values 7 and 25 – are not very precious for us and are often worth more (if not, they are “cheaper” for us) compared to what Player 2 might get if his draw is on the higher side. It makes sense to offer these fully.

Step 3: Form a candidate offer.
Let our offer indicate that we are “giving” a certain number of units to Player 2 (and we keep the rest). For our initial offer we propose:
 • Give Player 2 all 5 units of item 1.
 • Give Player 2 all 2 units of item 2.
 • Keep all 5 units of item 3 (offer 0 units to opponent).
 • For item 4, we concede 2 units (so we keep 2 out of 4).
 • For item 5, we concede 2 units (so we keep 3 out of 5).

Step 4: Check share values.
Our share then becomes:
 – Item 1: 0 units × 7 = 0 
 – Item 2: 0 units × 25 = 0 
 – Item 3: 5 units × 87 = 435 
 – Item 4: 2 units × 59 = 118 
 – Item 5: 3 units × 55 = 165 
Total = 435 + 118 + 165 = 718, which exceeds our reservation 627.

Under an assumed approximation (using an average value around 51 per unit) Player 2’s share would be roughly:
 – Item 1: 5 × ~51 = 255
 – Item 2: 2 × ~51 = 102
 – Item 4: 2 × ~51 = 102
 – Item 5: 2 × ~51 = 102
Summing roughly 255 + 102 + 102 + 102 = 561. This should be competitive with his outside offer (which is drawn uniformly from 1 up to his total possible value) and may motivate him to accept rather than delay—especially given the discounting that will occur in later rounds.

Step 5: Conclusion.
Based on our analysis, we aim to maximize our own value (718 if agreed immediately) while still giving Player 2 a share that, given the uncertainty of his private values, is likely to exceed his alternative. Therefore, in round 1 we propose our initial offer as follows.

I want to compare the current deal to my outside option and my “ideal” split from my own values. My private values over the 5 items are: item 1 = 78, item 2 = 100, item 3 = 69, item 4 = 28, item 5 = 71. (The totals for the items are 4, 2, 6, 7, and 6 respectively, so if I got everything my value would be 1548.) I also have an outside offer of 1321 that I would get if I walk away.

The current offer on the table gives me [0, 0, 6, 4, 0] so that my “share” (the items offered to me) is:
 • 0 units of item 1 → 0 (0 × 78)
 • 0 units of item 2 → 0 (0 × 100)
 • 6 units of item 3 → 414 (6 × 69)
 • 4 units of item 4 → 112 (4 × 28)
 • 0 units of item 5 → 0 (0 × 71)
For a total (undiscounted) of 526. In round 2 the discount is γ^(2–1) = 0.98 so its present value is only about 515. This is much less than my outside offer of 1321.

Because the current deal is far worse than my outside option, I should not ACCEPT it. (I also do not want to WALK now because if I can agree on even a slim deal in round 2 I’d get a (discounted) “deal value” of about 0.98×V and I can get somewhat more than my 1321 if V is high enough.) So the idea is to propose a counteroffer that gives me almost everything I value highly while “sacrificing” only items I care little about.

My total full value is 1548, and to beat my outside offer my present‐value deal (if reached in round 2) must satisfy:
  0.98 × (my share’s undiscounted value) ≥ 1321.
That means my undiscounted value must be at least 1321/0.98 ≈ 1348. In other words, I can “afford” to give away up to 1548 – 1348 = 200 “value‐points.”

Looking at my own item values, item 4 is the cheapest (only 28 per unit) so I can concede those without “losing” too much. (Conceding even one unit of a high‐value item would cost me nearly 70–100 points.) In fact, if I give all 7 units of item 4 away, I lose 7 × 28 = 196 “points.” This keeps my retained value at 1548 – 196 = 1352, which after discounting (0.98 × 1352 ≈ 1325) is just slightly above my outside offer.

Incidentally, note that my round‐1 offer was exactly [0, 0, 0, 7, 0] (i.e. giving away all of item 4). Player 2’s round‐1 counteroffer was [0, 0, 6, 4, 0] (telling me that they would give me 6 items of type 3 and 4 of type 4) which yields me only 526 in value. With my strong outside option I must insist on a division that almost gives me everything except the “cheap” item type 4. Therefore, even though my first proposal was rejected, my best counteroffer in round 2 is to propose again that I receive everything except item 4—in other words, offer Player 2 all 7 units of item 4 and keep the rest.

Thus, my counteroffer is that I give Player 2 the 7 units of item 4 (and nothing else), which corresponds to a counteroffer vector for Player 2 of: [0, 0, 0, 7, 0]. This would leave me with [4, 2, 6, 0, 6] which I value at 312 + 200 + 414 + 0 + 426 = 1352 (undiscounted), and at 0.98 × 1352 ≈ 1325 once discounted. That is marginally better than my outside offer, so it should be acceptable to me. (Of course, Player 2’s response is unknown; if they reject I can still WALK and get 1321.)

Therefore, my action is:

In round 3 any negotiated deal’s raw value is multiplied by γ^(r–1) = 0.98² ≈ 0.9604. In order to beat my fallback, any deal I accept must give me an un‐discounted value of roughly at least

Looking at the current offer from Player 2 – which gives me [0,0,6,7,2] units – my share would be:

 • Item 4: 7 units → 7×28 = 196
 • Item 5: 6 units → 6×71 = 426
for a total of 1548. But the current offer would mean Player 2 is keeping [4,2,0,0,4] (since the offer on the table is what I get from Player 2’s proposal). In fact, the current offer that gives me [0,0,6,7,2] means I would be giving up many of the items I value highly (like items 1, 2, and 5). In other words, accepting that offer would leave me with only 752 in raw value (414 + 196 + 142) – and discounted that is only about 722 – which is far less than my outside option of 1321.

I could consider a counteroffer. For example, if I attempted to “save” most of my strong items and concede only on the item type that I value the lowest (item 4 at 28 per unit), then if I concede 6 units of item 4 (leaving me 1 unit of item 4), I keep:

 • Item 3: all 6 units (6×69 = 414)
 • Item 4: 1 unit (1×28 = 28)
 • Item 5: all 6 units (6×71 = 426)
Total raw value = 312+200+414+28+426 = 1380, which discounts to about 1380×0.9604 ≈ 1325 – only slightly above my fallback of 1321. (In such a counteroffer I would have to offer Player 2 [0,0,0,6,0].)

Given that a counteroffer that barely beats my outside alternative leaves very little “margin” and may not even entice Player 2 (especially since we have no information on their exact valuations and outside option), it would be risky to try and negotiate further. My guaranteed outside offer of 1321 is substantially better than what’s being offered on the table, and any counteroffer I can credibly propose in round 3 comes out very marginally above that—and then there is a risk of no deal. 

Thus, my best response in round 3 is to WALK away and take my outside offer.

I'll explain my reasoning.

My goal is to secure as much of the high‐value “pie” as possible while offering Player 2 a bundle that is likely to be at least as good as (or only slightly below) what they might expect if the negotiation continues. I know my own item‐values very well. In my case item 2 is very precious (95 per unit) and item 4 is also quite valuable (55 per unit), whereas my values for item 1 (12), item 3 (14) and item 5 (10) are relatively lower. (My total value for all items is 919.) My own outside offer is 269, so any accepted deal should beat that. On the other hand, I do not know Player 2’s private values; they are drawn uniformly between 1 and 101 for each item. On average each unit is worth roughly 51 to them so (if they got all items) their total would be around 1071. Their outside offer is drawn from [1, total] so on average it is roughly half of that – around 535. (But note it might vary.) 

In a three‐round alternating‐offers game with a discount factor of γ = 0.98 per round, the proposer (me) has an incentive to claim the items I value highly while offering Player 2 extras on items I don’t care much about. A natural way to “price” the goods is to concede almost everything on low‐value items. Thus I propose to offer Player 2 all of item 1 (6 units), all of item 3 (3 units) and all of item 5 (3 units) so that they get a complete bundle on those “cheaper” items. In exchange I would keep nearly all of item 2 (which I value at 95 each) and item 4 (which I value at 55 each).

This offer is aggressive from my side. In my final allocation I would receive item 2’s full 7 units and item 4’s full 2 units. My resulting utility would be 
  7×95 + 2×55 = 665 + 110 = 775,
which is well above my outside offer of 269. Meanwhile if Player 2’s private numbers are around the average of 51 per unit, then the bundle of items 1, 3, and 5 would be worth roughly 
  (6+3+3)×51 = 12×51 = 612,
which should be competitive compared to an outside offer drawn from their own total.

Thus, using this “slicing” of the cake according to our relative item‐preferences seems reasonable for an initial offer in round 1.

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives.

    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

We first try to “set the bar” for ourselves. Recall that if the deal does not go through we get our “outside offer” (803 in our case) while the items all together would give us a total of 1028 if we got everything. In other words, we “own” a surplus of 1028 – 803 = 225 in terms of our own value that we can risk “giving away” in order to make the offer attractive to Player 2. (Player 2’s own outside offer is private, but on average the opponent’s total‐value is about 918 so – by a rough average – they might expect an outside value around (918+1)/2 ≈ 459. Thus, if our offer “handed over” items to them that (in our own calculation) have a total “expected worth” of only less than roughly 460 they might prefer waiting.) 

Because our negotiation is over 5 kinds of items with different counts (item 1:4, item 2:4, item 3:4, item 4:2, item 5:4) and because our “private” per‑unit values are very different across items (item 1:6, item 2:87, item 3:88, item 4:28, item 5:62), a natural idea is to “concede” the items that are “cheap” for us while (likely) being “more valuable” to Player 2. (Player 2’s per‑unit values are drawn uniformly from 1 to 101 so their average is roughly 51.) In our case item 1 is very cheap for us (6 per unit) and on average would be about 51 to Player 2; similarly, item 4 is modest for us (28 per unit versus an average of about 51). In contrast, we value items 2 and 3 very highly (87–88 per unit) so we prefer to keep those. Item 5 is “in between” (62 for us, versus an average of 51).

Now, note that if we took “everything” we’d get 1028 in our value. But since we must beat our outside offer (803), we can “afford” to give away up to 225 (in our valuation) to Player 2. Our aim is then to “minimize” the items we reserve for ourselves (so as to maximize what we grant to Player 2) but still keep at least 803 in value. (Each unit we keep “costs” from our available surplus while each unit we give away is “cheap” if it is an item we don’t mind forfeiting.) 

Let yᵢ be the number of units we keep (for item i) and xᵢ the units offered to Player 2 (with yᵢ + xᵢ equal to the total available for item i). Our own total value is

  6·y₁ + 87·y₂ + 88·y₃ + 28·y₄ + 62·y₅

and we need this to be at least 803. Our total “pie” in units is 4 + 4 + 4 + 2 + 4 = 18 units. In order to maximize the “share” we offer, we want to minimize “y₁ + y₂ + y₃ + y₄ + y₅” subject to the above constraint.

Since our highest per‑unit values come from items 2 and 3, we prefer to keep those entirely. So we set y₂ = 4 and y₃ = 4 (yielding 4·87 + 4·88 = 348 + 352 = 700). We’re then short by 803 – 700 = 103. Next, the “best” way to cover the shortfall is to take units from the remaining items in which we have a higher “bang‐for‐buck” (i.e. high monetary contribution per unit kept). Item 5 pays 62 per unit; so if we keep 2 units (2·62 = 124) then our total reserved value becomes 700 + 124 = 824 ≥ 803. (Had we instead “reserved” units from item 1 or item 4 we’d be “paying” far more of our “225‐concession budget” because item 1 gives only 6 per unit and item 4 only 28 per unit.) 

Thus one way to “minimize” our kept units is to take:
  y₂ = 4, y₃ = 4, y₅ = 2 (with y₁ = 0 and y₄ = 0).
Our “kept” total number of units is then 4 + 4 + 2 = 10 and our “offered” (given away) units become
  x₁ = 4  (since total item 1 is 4),
  x₂ = 0,
  x₃ = 0,
  x₄ = 2  (since total item 4 is 2),
  x₅ = 4 – 2 = 2.
In our own valuation the “concession” amounts to
  item 1: 4·6 = 24,
  item 4: 2·28 = 56,
  item 5: 2·62 = 124,
so that total given away is 24 + 56 + 124 = 204—which is within our sacrifice allowance (225). (We cannot “afford” a concession exceeding 225 because then our own deal would drop below 803.)

In terms of expected value for Player 2 (assuming an average per‑unit value near 51), the offered items would “look like”
  item 1: 4·51 ≈ 204,
  item 4: 2·51 ≈ 102,
  item 5: 2·51 ≈ 102,
summing to about 408. (While this is a bit below the “average” outside offer one might expect for Player 2, note that Player 2’s actual type is private; some types value these items less than 51.) Also note that early in negotiations one generally begins with a somewhat “greedy” offer. 

Thus, our initial offer to Player 2 is to give them:
  item 1: 4 units,
  item 2: 0 units,
  item 3: 0 units,
  item 4: 2 units,
  item 5: 2 units.
This leaves us with:
  item 1: 0,
  item 2: 4,
  item 3: 4,
  item 4: 0,
  item 5: 2,
which totals a value of 824 (above our outside offer) for ourselves.

Accordingly, my round 1 action is to propose that initial division, i.e.:

 • Item 4: 18 (7 units available),
 • Item 5: 12 (2 units available).

I also know that a deal will be discounted by gamma^(r–1) (with gamma = 0.98) so getting agreement quickly is an advantage. In round 1 there is no discount yet. Although I do not know Player 2’s private per‑unit values or their outside offer (which is drawn from a uniform range up to their total value), I do know that if I offer too “stingy” a division they might prefer waiting or relying on their outside option. At the same time I want to keep the high‐value item (item 1) for myself. 

A standard idea in negotiations is to “steal” the items that are most valuable to me (here item 1) while splitting items of lower relative value more equally. For item 1 I propose giving Player 2 nothing. For the others I offer roughly half (or a little more than half of the items, since light “concessions” in some types help secure a deal). For instance, giving over 3 units of item 2 (out of 6), 1 unit of item 3 (out of 3), 3 units of item 4 (out of 7), and 1 unit of item 5 (out of 2) gives Player 2 the bundle [0, 3, 1, 3, 1]. Then I receive the remaining items: item 1 (1 unit), item 2 (3 units), item 3 (2 units), item 4 (4 units), and item 5 (1 unit).

 • Item 4: 4 × 18 = 72

This total of 352 (before any discount, and well above my outside offer of 78) is attractive from my point of view. At the same time, the offered bundle [0, 3, 1, 3, 1] gives Player 2 a reasonable allocation (especially since I have “bought” keeping item 1) that may exceed their outside option. I reason as follows. I know my own values for the types:
 • Item 1 (1 unit): 94
 • Item 2 (2 units): 19 each
 • Item 3 (2 units): 59 each
 • Item 4 (2 units): 5 each
 • Item 5 (3 units): 87 each
so if I got everything I’d have 521 points. (My outside offer is only 15, so a deal is far better for me.) In an alternating offer game the proposer—in this case me—can “keep” most of what it values highly while giving the other side enough so that (given the discounting and the alternative of waiting for their own offer) they are at least as well off as from their outside option. Although I don’t know Player 2’s private values, I can reason on the basis of expectation. Because the values for each item are drawn uniformly on [1,101] the average value of any unit is about 51 for Player 2. (Their total “all‐items” value is 510 in expectation, so their reservation outside offer – drawn uniformly from 1 to that amount – is on average about 255.) 

I consider that I really want to secure my “prized” items: item 1 (worth 94 to me), both of item 3 (each 59) and most of item 5 (each 87). In contrast, item 2 (worth only 19 per unit to me) and item 4 (only 5 per unit) are relatively unimportant. So a natural idea is to “sacrifice” items 2 and 4 by giving them entirely to Player 2. (This guarantees that in any realization, if Player 2’s private numbers on these items turn out high, their allocated value from them will be sufficiently attractive.) However, if I gave over all of my “less‐valued” items it would give them an expected value of about 2×51 (for item 2) plus 2×51 (for item 4), which is around 204. That stands a good chance of being below their reservation (roughly 255 on average), especially since the game discounts future rounds. 

To keep my own payoff high while nudging Player 2’s expected deal value toward what they might get if they were to wait, I decide to “tweak” the offer by including one extra unit from one of the high–quantity items. I cannot risk giving away item 1 (which I value highly at 94), and item 3 is also too precious (59 each), so the best candidate is giving up one unit of item 5 (worth 87 to me). In this way my proposal becomes:

 Offer to give Player 2: 
  • 0 units of item 1 (I keep the one unit),
  • 2 units of item 2 (the full amount),
  • 0 units of item 3 (I keep both units),
  • 2 units of item 4 (the full amount),
  • 1 unit of item 5 (out of 3; I keep 2).

With this offer Player 2 ends up with items that on average have value ≈2×51 (item 2) + 2×51 (item 4) + 51 (item 5) ≈255 – roughly matching the typical outside value they might have. (Also note that in later rounds the discount factor of 0.98 would make waiting slightly less attractive.) Meanwhile my own allocation is high‐valued: item 1 gives 94, item 3 gives 2×59 = 118, and item 5 gives 2×87 = 174 (totaling 94+118+174 = 386), which is significantly better than my outside offer of 15.

Thus, as my first move in round 1 I choose the following counteroffer:
